comments.text:
Seems like every technologically super-advanced military corporation lately 
chooses the name Atlas, huh?﻿
comments.author: Karl Mart (Necrostigman)

comments.text:
Nah, it makes the gods seem like twats; Atlas, a hero, who protects the 
world - I mean If It was me I'd just drop it and be like whatcha gonna do 
pricks, but he's clearly a good guy though his cause was 'wrong' right? So 
by that measure the gods are pretty much a group of 5yr olds who like to 
punish for the lolz. So, back to the original topic, someone who is doomed 
to fail and leave the means for others to fight on in his stead, even 
though it means assisting the enemy? (similarly to how the mechs are used 
against them)
comments.author: Quackers McGee

comments.text:
+Karl Mart True, but consider the symbolism: Atlas, the titan who holds up 
the skies and prevents the world below from being crushed. Atlas, who 
fought against the gods of olympus and in defeat was given the duty of 
protecting the entire world from certain demise. Sounds pretty noble if you 
phrase it correctly.

comments.author: epiclifeross

comments.text:
It's sad I discovered Monty's work posthumously. He's left a legacy, and 
will continue to inspire people even after his death. He's shown me that 
achieving your dreams is possible. He seemed to be an hardworking, and 
awesome person. I wish I could have met him before his untimely passing. It 
happens too often that creative people are lost, and the number of 
unoriginal, phony, and uninspired people outnumber those who actually have 
a creative passion, and something they strive to make a reality. His works 
will continue to inspire me, and push me forward to accomplish my dreams. 
Goodbye Monty, you will be missed.﻿
